title: Why did some people hate Ronald Reagan? What are reasons that people may have for holding Reagan and his legacy in low regard? - Quora
tags: Why Do People Hate X So Much?

response.answer_text: Thanks for the A2A. Those of us who dislike Reagan dislike him for the following reasons: He embraced the "greed is good" philosophy. Reagan made it acceptable for people to be self centered. We no longer have a sense of interconnectedness as a society because of Reagan. We also as a society spend a lot of time worshiping wealth and those that have it in large part because of the economic philosophies and deification of the business/free market  that Reagan ushered in. Rich=good, hardworking, smart, and poor equals=lazy, stupid. This philosophy has resulted in the cruel cuts in our social safety net-after all, if you believe that poor people are lazy, stupid, and are poor because they made bad decisions, it's easier to cut them off and let them fend for themselves. He started the trend of enriching the rich at the expense of the poor. Reagan's tax decreases largely benefited the very richest Americans at the expense of everyone else. Many people are not aware that Reagan raised taxes on the middle class-he hiked the payroll taxes on working Americans and removed deductions from the tax code that middle class Americans largely benefitted from, such as being able to deduct interests on consumer loans. He devalued the role and purpose of government. Reagan took the first giant steps toward discrediting the role of government as a solution to problems. His quip that "the  scariest words were 'I'm from the government, and I'm here to help'" made a lot of people laugh and clap, but in reality, his philosophy as embodied in those  words  resulted in a mistrust in the government as an agent of change so large that Republicans nowadays don't even pretend to govern anymore. And Democrats, in order to win elections, have had to incorporate that philosophy as well to some degree-Clinton's statement "the era of big government is over" is an explicit acknowledgement of how powerful a grip this philosophy regarding government's role in our society had become. We now have people running for office who don't believe in the government as a tool for crafting the society that we want to have, and that is having far reaching effects on our ability to solve such problems as wealth inequality, poverty, education,  climate change, unemployment, and other issues. To a lesser degree, he continued the Republican party's race problem. Most notably, at his appearance at a rally in Philadelphia, Mississippi, where he stated he was for "states rights". Sound innocuous? Well, only if you didn't know that was where four civil rights workers were killed fighting for the right to vote for blacks. Not to mention his lies regarding "welfare queens" and "strong young bucks" driving Cadillacs around while collecting welfare checks. The Republicans had a race problem prior to Reagan, but he certainly didn't improve it.

I don't hate the man at all. But in terms of his policies: the short-and-sweet version: Sold arms to terrorists, denied it, then used the proceeds to circumvent the constitution, then denied that. Eventually reversed both denials when they no longer held water.Ran as a debt-hating conservative, then busted the budget. The national debt went up 186% (as opposed to Obama's 44%).A very late and small response to the AIDS crisis. c.f. Reagan's AIDS Legacy / Silence equals death or Flashback: The Reagan White House Thought AIDS Was Pretty HilariousRacism. from launching his campaign in a town best known for being the site of the murder of civil rights workers, to talking about african-americans as "bucks" and "welfare queens" to dragging feet as long as possible on honoring MLK (even refusing, shortly before making MLK day a holiday, to say whether MLK was a communist) to backing apartheid in South Africa to...Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and Interior heads who were anti-environmentalists. c.f. A look back at Reagan's environmental recordAssigning and keeping a HUD head who had no interest in HUD; those under him ran riot: “a pervasive pattern of criminal behavior” “replete with waste, fraud and abuse” resulted in “widespread abuses, influence peddling, blatant favoritism, monumental waste and gross mismanagement” (source). Investigation eventually “uncovered "significant problems" of fraud, theft, mismanagement, and influence-peddling in 94 percent of HUD's budget. Estimated losses from this abuse ranged from $2 billion to $6 billion” (emphasis added) (source).
